sample.title: The Infinite Explorer With Hannah Fry Trailer | Premieres Nov. 2
sample.description:
The Infinite Explorer with Hannah Fry seeks out extraordinary local voices and unexpected quirks of history and geography that reveal what makes each place truly unique. With Fry‚Äôs famous curiosity, wit and insight, she peels back the layers of six iconic nations: Spain, Vietnam, Greece, South Korea, Ireland and Iceland.

The all-new series will air Mondays at 8 p.m. ET starting Nov. 2 on Bloomberg Originals, available on major streaming platforms such as Samsung TV+, Prime Video Channels and LG channels. It will also air at 10 p.m. ET on Bloomberg TV and be available on-demand on Bloomberg.com and YouTube.

sample.title: What Gold‚Äôs Rise (Really) Means for the World
sample.description:
Gold‚Äôs price per ounce surged past $4,000 this month, a record-breaking rally tied in part to eroding confidence in the US dollar. Uncertainty driven by Donald Trump‚Äôs trade war as well as questions about the independence of the Federal Reserve and America‚Äôs wavering economy have also played a part. Add to that heightened geopolitical tensions across the globe and you have a recipe for a mass flight to gold. And that‚Äôs exactly what central banks and investors have been doing. 

Now with China seeking to offer an alternative to American dominance, we look at what gold‚Äôs historic rise means for the global financial system. 

Read more: Why Investors Can‚Äôt Seem to Get Enough of Gold
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2025-10-16/gold-price-record-how-us-china-ten[‚Ä¶]s-fed-cut-bets-are-driving-bullion-rally?utm_medium=social&utm_source=youtube&utm_campaign=originals&utm_content=article

Sign up for the Economics Daily newsletter to discover what's driving the global economy and what it means for policy makers, businesses, investors and you.
https://www.bloomberg.com/account/newsletters/new-economy-daily

sample.title: How Wawa Is Taking Share From Burger King And Starbucks
sample.description:
One of America‚Äôs largest convenience store chains, Wawa, has gained a cultlike following in its home markets of Philadelphia and South Jersey due to its sharp focus on food and customer service. Its revenue is estimated to have more than doubled since 2014, and its workforce has grown nearly 90% since 2016 as it rapidly expands to other areas of the country. So, can the nearly $19 billion convenience chain take on major chains and local players like 7-Eleven, Buc-ee's and Casey's General Stores?

sample.title: How Nike‚Äôs New CEO Plans To Turn Things Around
sample.description:
Nike is the world‚Äôs largest sportswear brand, but after several quarters of disappointing results, its comeback plan is just beginning. Longtime executive Elliott Hill, who came out of retirement to become CEO, says he‚Äôs betting on a ‚Äúreturn to sport‚Äù to revive the brand. In an exclusive interview at Nike‚Äôs Oregon headquarters, Hill tells CNBC‚Äôs Sara Eisen how he‚Äôs reorganizing the company by sport, rebuilding ties with wholesale partners, and reenergizing its innovation pipeline to compete with fast-growing rivals like On and Hoka. But big challenges remain ‚Äî from cleaning up excess inventory to navigating tariffs and a sales slowdown in China. Watch the full story to see how Hill plans to get Nike back on top.

sample.title: Why EVs Depreciate Faster Than Gas Cars
sample.description:
EV‚Äôs are cheaper to operate than a gas car, but their resale values are horrible. It‚Äôs a mix of factors - incentives, changing tech and limited appeal. It‚Äôs a problem for EV adoption, especially as automakers try to attract more mainstream buyers. Here‚Äôs why they can be more expensive to own than a gas car, and why that might change.

sample.title: Why younger Americans are saving money at such a high rate
sample.description:
As Americans live longer and worry about outlasting their money in retirement, a growing number are counting on one strategy for their future financial security: working longer.

Roughly 70% of U.S. workers who haven‚Äôt retired yet have considered pushing back their retirement date, according to a recent survey from F&G, an insurance company. Nearly half of the 2,000 adults surveyed said they‚Äôre afraid they won‚Äôt have enough money to retire.

sample.title: The $1 Trillion Tangled Web Of AI Deals Mapped Out
sample.description:
The pace and scale of artificial intelligence infrastructure deals lately has been staggering, with OpenAI, the maker of ChatGPT, alone racking up around one trillion dollars worth of AI deals this year. These interconnected investments between companies like Nvidia, Oracle, Broadcom, CoreWeave, Meta, Google, AMD, Microsoft and others have dramatically lifted the valuations of many of the companies involved and sent U.S. stock indexes soaring. But some experts are worried that this tangled web of deals is reminiscent of the dotcom bubble.

Produced by: Magdalena Petrova
Animation: Christina Locopo
Additional Reporting: Kif Lewsing, Ashley Capoot, Mackenzie Sigalos
Edited by: Erin Black
Senior Director of Video: Jeniece Pettitt
Additional Footage: Getty Images

sample.title: What are the new allegations against Prince Andrew? | BBC Newscast
sample.description:
Today, new allegations against Prince Andrew have appeared in the Sunday newspapers, accusing him of asking his police protection to investigate Virginia Giuffre just before the newspaper published a photo of her alleged first meeting with the prince. Prince Andrew has not commented on the reports, but consistently denies all allegations against him.

Victoria Derbyshire and Simon Jack stand in for Laura and Paddy, joining Henry to discuss the latest accusations as well as what options are left for politicians, and the Royal Family, as Giuffre‚Äôs brother asks for the King to strip Andrew of his title as Prince.

Plus, how do we get our energy bills down? Energy secretary Ed Milliband, his shadow Claire Coutinho, and Green party leader Zack Polanski all spoke to Victoria this morning and offered alternative visions. But what do the public want?

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#BBCNews

sample.title: Hunt continues for thieves after jewels stolen in heist at Louvre museum in Paris | BBC News
sample.description:
The Louvre museum in Paris is closed after a heist on Sunday morning.

The French interior ministry says a number of people broke into the Apollo Gallery via a mechanised lift and took jewels. The thieves are said to have been carrying small chainsaws and escaped on a scooter.

The French government says the items taken are of 'incalculable' value but that no injuries were reported and an investigation is under way.

Culture Minister Rachida Dati told French TV that in their haste to flee, one stolen item was found underneath the Louvre.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#LouvreMuseum #Paris #BBCNews

sample.title: Hunt continues for thieves after heist at Louvre museum in Paris. #Paris #Louvre #BBCNews
Thieves steal jewels of 'incalculable' value in heist at Louvre museum in Paris | BBC News
sample.description:
The Louvre Museum in Paris has been closed following a robbery, France's culture minister says.

Rachida Dati wrote on X that the robbery happened on Sunday morning as the museum was opening. She said she was at the site, where police are investigating

The museum confirmed it was closing for the day "for exceptional reasons," without providing further details.

French media reports say jewellery has been stolen, after three masked men reportedly used a freight lift under renovation to access the Apollo Gallery, where what remains of France's crown jewels are kept. The gallery is on the side of the River Seine.

The thieves are said to have broken windows to gain entry before escaping on motor scooters. They also had chainsaws. The value of the stolen items is not yet known.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#Paris #TheLouvre #BBCNews
